page.title: 09A FARMERS DAY
page.content: A farmer in{West Torrington}begins work at 7.30am. He starts by seeing his men, and allocating the days tasks. He has no stock, so he may join with his men in ploughing, cultivating or spraying, or may be occupied with other jobs, such as fetching spare parts, taking corn to the mill or beet to the sugar factory, or interviewing representatives of e.g. fertilizer makers or corn merchants. He has his breakfast at 9.30am, a snack lunch at 1pm, and dinner about 5pm. Similar types of work occupy the spaces between meals, except at harvest, which can begin in late July and continue into mid-September, depending on the weather. Then, combining,and carting the crop back to the farm begins as soon as the crop is dry enough in the morning, and continues until the dew is too heavy at dusk.
